<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 384, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 892, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 765, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 548, 359, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

Cshinyblack
Dshinywhite
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 486, 107, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 486, 912, 504]]<|/det|> A large hill blocks the direct path between a transmitter of radio waves and a receiver, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 512, 839, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 897, 673]]<|/det|> The receiver picks up the signal from the transmitter even though the radio waves do not travel through the hill. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 685, 297, 701]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 648, 858]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 740, 91]]<|/det|>
Identical resistors are connected together to form arrangements X, Y and Z.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 97, 912, 200]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 913, 231]]<|/det|>
What is the correct order of the resistances of the arrangements from the largest to the smallest?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 241, 139, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 241, 250, 259]]<|/det|>
X \(\rightarrow\) Y \(\rightarrow\) Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 139, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 268, 250, 286]]<|/det|>
Y \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 295, 139, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 295, 250, 313]]<|/det|>
Z \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 139, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 322, 250, 341]]<|/det|>
Z \(\rightarrow\) Y \(\rightarrow\) X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 368, 102, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 700, 387]]<|/det|>
Resistors of \(1.0\Omega\), \(2.0\Omega\) and \(3.0\Omega\) are connected in parallel with a cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 348, 416]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 426, 133, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 426, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
The current in each resistor is different but the potential difference (p.d.) across each resistor is the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 467, 133, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 467, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
The current in each resistor is the same but the potential difference across each resistor is different.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 133, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 509, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
The potential difference across the \(3.0\Omega\) is greater than the potential difference across the \(1.0\Omega\) resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
The sum of the potential differences across each resistor is equal to the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 612, 107, 629]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 611, 452, 629]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circuit component.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 655, 567, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 707, 279, 724]]<|/det|>
What is it used for?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 735, 133, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 735, 452, 753]]<|/det|>
to allow current in one direction only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 762, 133, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 762, 460, 780]]<|/det|>
to change the direction of the current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 789, 133, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 789, 445, 807]]<|/det|>
to emit light when there is a current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 816, 133, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 816, 432, 833]]<|/det|>
to increase the size of the current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 811, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 180, 141, 199]]<|/det|>

AND

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 225, 107, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 609, 244]]<|/det|>
Where must a fuse be connected in a mains electric circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 138, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 254, 306, 272]]<|/det|>
the earth wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 138, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 280, 293, 299]]<|/det|>
the live wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 307, 133, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 307, 322, 325]]<|/det|>
the neutral wire only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 333, 138, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 333, 406, 351]]<|/det|>
the live wire and the earth wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 377, 107, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 787, 395]]<|/det|>
The N-pole of a magnet is moved into a coil of wire connected to a galvanometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 405, 628, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 668, 564, 686]]<|/det|>
Use a coil with more turns and a stronger magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 134, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 694, 559, 712]]<|/det|>
Use a coil with more turns and a weaker magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 739, 106, 757]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 471, 104, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 571, 491]]<|/det|> Plutonium-238 decays by the emission of an \(\alpha\) -particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 501, 663, 521]]<|/det|> Which equation represents the decay of a plutonium-238 nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 533, 134, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 532, 401, 560]]<|/det|> \(^{238}\mathrm {Pu}\rightarrow ^{238}\mathrm {U}\ +\ ^{0}_{-1}\alpha\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 134, 595]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 573, 390, 600]]<|/det|> \(^{238}\mathrm {Pu}\rightarrow ^{234}\mathrm {U}\ +\ ^{4}_{2}\alpha\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 134, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 612, 390, 640]]<|/det|> \(^{238}\mathrm {Pu}\rightarrow ^{234}\mathrm {U}\ +\ ^{2}_{4}\alpha\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 134, 677]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 655, 390, 682]]<|/det|> \(^{238}\mathrm {Pu}\rightarrow ^{242}\mathrm {U}\ +\ ^{4}_{2}\alpha\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 714, 104, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 714, 490, 734]]<|/det|> A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 8 days. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 745, 838, 780]]<|/det|> A detector close to a sample of this isotope gives a count rate of 200 counts per minute. Without the source, the background count is 20 counts per minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 791, 561, 810]]<|/det|> What is the count rate due to the source after 8 days? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 820, 134, 838]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 820, 329, 838]]<|/det|> 80 counts per minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 846, 133, 864]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 846, 329, 864]]<|/det|> 90 counts per minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 873, 133, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 873, 339, 890]]<|/det|> 100 counts per minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 898, 133, 917]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 898, 339, 917]]<|/det|> 110 counts per minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 680, 89]]<|/det|>
Why are some radioactive sources stored in boxes made from lead?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 118]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 599, 118]]<|/det|>
Lead absorbs emissions from the radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 134, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 127, 574, 144]]<|/det|>
Lead decreases the half-life of radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 134, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 153, 567, 170]]<|/det|>
Lead increases the half-life of radioactive sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 180, 134, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 180, 584, 197]]<|/det|>
Lead repels emissions from the radioactive sources.
